item.title: The Lede: Latest Updates on Election Day in Iran
item.description: The Lede is following developments in Iran, where voters went to the polls on Friday in the first presidential election since the disputed contest in 2009.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: A screenshot of a chart on the vote count in Iran from the international public opinion and research firm IPOS.

item.title: Moderate in Iranian Election Takes Strong Lead in Early Returns
item.description: The cleric Hassan Rowhani, the field’s most moderate candidate, held a decisive edge in preliminary results, followed by Mohammad Baqer Ghalibaf, Tehran’s popular mayor.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: Hassan Rowhani, waving his ballot, was one of six candidates running for president. Early tallies had Mr. Rowhani, a moderate cleric, gaining a strong lead, according to the interior minister.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: June 15
item.description: Syrian rebels weigh prospects; war crimes tribunal rift; Argentines turn from beef; trade deal in Europe; and a new Airbus jet.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:description: A rebel fighter from the Grandsons of the Prophet Brigade at Deir Al Gharbi, a front line close to Syrian Army positions, May 30.

item.title: Moderate in Iranian Election Leads in Initial Returns
item.description: Iran’s interior minister said Saturday morning that preliminary results showed Hassan Rowhani, a cleric, with a strong lead, followed by the mayor of Tehran, Mohammad Baqer Ghalibaf.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: Hassan Rowhani, waving his ballot, was one of six candidates running for president. Early tallies had Mr. Rowhani, a moderate cleric, gaining a strong lead, according to the interior minister.

item.title: A Myanmar in Transition Says Little of Past Abuses
item.description: Men who were at the helm of a repressive government have moved on easily in a democracy, in part, because there have been few calls for trials or war crimes tribunals.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: U Khin Nyunt, a much-feared former spymaster, at his home in Yangon, Myanmar, on Wednesday. He now spends his mornings praying amid Buddhist statues, and also has an art gallery.

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Protest in China Over Sentence Given to Dissident’s Brother-in-Law
item.description: In an open letter to President Xi Jinping, Liu Xia said the sentencing last Sunday had been unfair and urged Mr. Xi to govern China in a way that respects the rights of individuals and avoids “ruthless suppression based on violence.”
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: United Nations Soldier in Sudan Is Slain
item.description: A United Nations peacekeeper was killed on Friday in Sudan’s main oil region when shells struck a logistics base, a United Nations spokesman said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Millions Spent to Deport Militant Cleric in Britain, but He Still Hasn’t Left
item.description: The cleric, Omar Mahmoud Mohammed Othman, said he would leave Britain voluntarily if Jordan ratifies a new treaty with Britain banning the use of torture-tainted evidence.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN F. BURNS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Vietnam Government Critic Arrested
item.description: Pham Viet Dao, one of the country’s best known bloggers, has been arrested for posting criticism of the government. So far this year, 38 bloggers or activists have been arrested.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Libya’s Television Channel Is a Target
item.description: Libya Al-Hurra, Libya’s first independent television channel, said Friday that a hand grenade was hurled at its building in the eastern city of Benghazi.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Prison Sentence for 2 Musicians Who Released Album of Protest Songs
item.description: The album has 12 songs, among them ones that praised the Dalai Lama, the exiled spiritual leader of the Tibetans, and the scores of Tibetans who have set themselves on fire since 2009 to protest Chinese rule.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: A Vote to Draft Women in Norway
item.description: Norway’s Parliament voted overwhelmingly on Friday to conscript women into its armed forces, becoming the first European and first NATO country to make military service compulsory for both men and women.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Court in Venezuela Orders Release of a Judge Once Scorned and Jailed by Chávez
item.description: Judge Lourdes Afiuni, imprisoned for more than three and a half years, had become a symbol of political persecution.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN and MARÍA EUGENIA DÍAZ

item.title: Some Protesters in Turkey Disavow Agreement With Premier to End Park Sit-In
item.description: Gezi Park remains occupied by defiant protesters who on Friday mostly disavowed a compromise between their self-declared leaders and Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
item.dc:creator: By CEYLAN YEGINSU and TIM ARANGO
item.media:credit: Ed Ou for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters remained in Taksim Square in Istanbul on Friday after self-described leaders reached a tentative deal with Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: A Briton’s Bitter Farewell to China Echoes Loudly
item.description: Mark Kitto, an entrepreneur, is leaving China after 16 years, saying the government protects its power at the expense of its people and citing concerns about raising his children.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mark Kitto moved out of his home in Moganshan, China, in May.

item.title: Aleppo Pounded, Rebels Weigh U.S. Vow of Aid
item.description: A rebel stronghold convulsed with some of the heaviest fighting in months, as activists debated how the United States’ decision to send arms would affect their fight to topple the Syrian president.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Heavy Pressure Led to Decision by Obama on Syrian Arms
item.description: When President Obama agreed to send small arms and ammunition to Syrian rebels, he had to be almost dragged into the decision by advisers, critics and even Bill Clinton.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER

item.title: New Bridge Over Danube Helps Dissolve Old Enmities
item.description: Leaders and locals on Friday celebrated a $340 million bridge over the Danube that should foster trade and ties between Romania and Bulgaria.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW BRUNWASSER
item.media:credit: Boryana Katsarova for The International Herald Tribune
item.media:description: Construction workers put some finishing touches on a new bridge spanning the Danube between Bulgaria and Romania.

item.title: Judge at War Crimes Tribunal Faults Acquittals of Serb and Croat Commanders
item.description: Frederik Harhoff of Denmark, a judge at the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia, suggested in a letter that the court’s president, an American, pressured judges in recent verdicts.
item.category: International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By MARLISE SIMONS

item.title: Player in Leaks Case, Out From Behind Camera
item.description: The documentarian Laura Poitras says her role in the leaking of American surveillance programs was “not something I was seeking out.”
item.dc:creator: By NOAM COHEN
item.media:description: Laura Poitras makes films about a world changed since 9/11.

item.title: Ecuador Legislature Approves Curbs on News Media
item.description: The measure, long sought by President Rafael Correa, would impose fines for coverage deemed by regulators as unfair.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN and MAGGY AYALA

item.title: The Pianist Davide Martello Calms Istanbul Tensions
item.description: When Davide Martello hauled a grand piano into Taksim Square in Istanbul and started playing, protesters and the police alike shared hours of calm.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU
item.media:credit: Ed Ou for The New York Times
item.media:description: The German pianist Davide Martello put himself and his grand piano at the center of the Taksim Square protest in Istanbul this week, with calming effects.

item.title: Differing Views on Privacy Shape Europe’s Response to U.S. Surveillance Program
item.description: While it is too early to know whether large numbers of Europeans will stop using American Internet services, the official European reaction has been loud and angry.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER and JACK EWING

item.title: Greek Broadcaster Fights Closure
item.description: A court decision expected Monday might lead to temporary revival of ERT, even as a prosecutor begins investigating the broadcaster’s finances.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: U.S. Allies Weigh Response to Chemical Weapons Charge
item.description: Syria said the Obama administration was “full of lies” in alleging the use of chemical weapons, and American allies were trying to decide what to do.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER and MARC SANTORA
